paragraphs.text: The rise of Poland's urban movement.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Poland's recent local elections went according to the usual script: The ruling coalition of the Civic Platform and Polish People's Party retained their control over major cities
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: But there was one political surprise in the final results
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The urban movement, which ran for the first time in elections as a nationwide coalition of city activists, won the mayor's seat in Gorzow Wielkopolski, in western Poland, and a number of city council seats in big cities like Warsaw, Poznan and Torun
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Although a newcomer to the electoral race, the urban movement dictated the direction of most election campaigns
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Their demands ended up in the electoral programmes of mainstream political parties
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which scrambled to attract grassroot activists on their lists to capture the youth leftist vote
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So what is this new political force and can it permanently transform Polish local and state politics?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In late 2007, a group of residents of the Rataje district in Poznan, in western Poland, organised to defend their right to have a say in the planning of their neighbourhood
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The mayor of Poznan and the city council, had proposed to transform the derelict post-industrial zone of the neighbourhood into a new residential and commercial area
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Local residents, on the other hand, insisted on building a park and a recreational area
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: They mobilised the community, organised protests, wrote petitions and publicised the issue in the media
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The negative publicity made the situation uncomfortable enough for local officials to concede to public pressure and withdraw their commercial development proposal
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This was the first sign that a new social force was emerging with the potential to affect urban policies in Poland through civic engagement
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Grassroot activities began to surface in other Polish cities around that time
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Activists from Sopot in northern Poland started calling for participatory budgeting following the model of the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In Lodz, in central Poland, an informal group of active citizens organised themselves around the issue of cleanliness of public spaces
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Gradually, these groups merged into a movement calling for citizen participation in the transformation of the post-industrial area of the city, just like in Poznan
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Lodz used to be an important industrial centre up until 1989
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: when
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: its textile industry collapsed
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: many industrial buildings lay abandoned and derelict
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In Warsaw, urban activists organised demonstrations for the preservation of green areas in the centre of the Polish capital; against hikes in public transport fees,;and against privatisation of municipal buildings
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In the last few years, groups like Right to the City, Inhabitants' Forum, and the Housing Movement have emerged in almost every Polish town bringing together individuals of various ages, social, and cultural backgrounds
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: These groups were involved in a variety of campaigns to reassert residents' rights to their neighbourhoods and towns: from writing petitions, to organising protests, pickets and demonstrations, to occupying vacant buildings, setting up squats and blocking evictions
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Their political appetite grew with time
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In 2010, Poznan activists formed:"We, the Inhabitants of Poznan," social electoral committee to contest local elections
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: They received almost 10 percent of the votes
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: with an electoral law favouring big political parties, they failed to get a seat on the council
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This electoral experience facilitated the launching, in 2011, of an informal coalition - the Urban Movements Congress - comprising urban activist groups from all over Poland
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The congress was tasked with formulating a programme to provide a common foundation around which urban activists would build their campaigns in local communities
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The programme was focused on three main pillars: policies to stem and reverse the growth of socioeconomic inequalities and exclusion; sustainable environment-conscious urban development in the interest of all residents; and promotion of direct democracy practices such as social consultations, participatory budgeting and referendums
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: After the founding of the congress, the urban movements grew in strength and impact
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: On the national level, the congress managed to pressure the Ministry of Regional Development to include some of its policies in its 2012 National Urban Policy (NUP) programme
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: On the local level, urban activists managed to reap a number of victories
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In 2011, after much "harassment" from activists, the mayor of Sopot agreed to implement participatory budgeting in the city
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Residents now can decide on how to spend 5 million zlotys (about $1.6m) or one percent of the municipal budget
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Other mayors soon followed suit
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In Lodz, residents decide on how to spend 40 million zlotys ($13m)
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The mayor of Lodz also invited local activists to advise the city council's Revitalisation Bureau on specific policies for the socioeconomic development of the city
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The reason why Lodz became more accepting of the urban movement's demands was because its previous mayor was removed in a popular referendum in January 2010
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The mayors of Czestochowa, Olsztyn, Elblag, Bytom and Ostroda were also removed in the same manner for introducing policies regarding privatisation and commercial development
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: which went against the will of their electorates
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The same fate threatened the mayor of Warsaw
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the low turnout at the referendum saved her
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: After surviving in her post, she quickly implemented some of the urban movement's demands
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But the most spectacular achievement of the Polish urban movement in recent months was putting Krakow's candidacy to host the 2022 Winter Olympic Games to a referendum
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: After it was announced in November 2013 that local authorities had decided to put forward Krakow's candidacy for the Olympics, activists launched a campaign called Krakow Against Games
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: which aimed to inform people of the negative consequences of hosting big sporting event
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: City authorities caved in under popular pressure and put the decision to a referendum, with the condition that it has at least a 30 percent turnout
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Knowing that the 2010 EU elections had only a 26 percent turnout
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: they combined the referendum with the 2014 EU elections
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: To the displeasure of local authorities, some 36 percent of Krakow's citizens voted
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: 70 percent of those said no to the games
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Victory of the Krakow Against Games campaign showed that referendums can be an important tool in bringing local policies in line with residents' will
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: that urban activists have considerable social support
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Krakow victory gave impetus to the formation by of nationwide coalition of 12 sociopolitical entities affiliated with the Urban Movements Congress to contest the 2014 local elections
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The results of the election demonstrated that the movement can translate its grassroot support into electoral victories
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: With the 2015 parliamentary and presidential elections approaching, the coalition is hopeful that it will have an even larger political impact in the coming year
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The urban movement has a long way to go in order to occupy a permanent place on Poland's political map
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: its public presence, successful campaigns and increasing social support show that there is a definite shift in Polish people's sociopolitical attitudes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There is clearly growing support for sustainable and environment-conscious development which aims to level out inequalities and exclusion and usher in effective practices of direct democracy
paragraphs.label: assumption
